postcontent:
Here I have a mint Steyr S9-A1. Very low round count and absolutely spotless. It comes with a ton of extra magazines - standard and high capacity magazines, brand new and never used, still in their packages. These magazines are not cheap and you will feel the quality of manufacturing Steyr puts into them.

More on the gun itself, it is comparable to a Glock 26 9mm but in my opinion ergonomically far superior. It has a higher tang grip for a much lower bore axis then its counter parts.  Grip angle provides a very natural draw on to target with a very fast target acquisition due to the trapezoid sights on the slide. Groupings are very tight for me and is a wonderful everyday carry.

Recoil is very manageable, it has a dual captive spring. robust design and with its flat wound spring with has an infinitely longer life then conventional coiled springs. The guide rod is made of steel and is machined with precision. place it on the table and you will see how straight it stands in its base. Do the same test with Glocks guide rod and you see the difference. 

The trigger, this is one of my favorite qualities of the gun. It is a short and crisp break in the action. With a very minimal reset, right out of the box. Upon firing it you will notice that the reset is very subtle and to some the thought of that is a negative but I will say the issue is negated by the fact that the reset is so very short with very little slack on the return. By the time you are waiting for the reset to end you are already at the take up to break the shot. its that fast. It breaks like a twig not a carrot as John Geissle would say about his AR triggers. 

I could go on and on about the pistol. The rails in which the slide glides on are 3x more robust then that of its counter parts; springfield, glock, etc. The rails are built within a stand alone chassis within the polymer frame of the gun which is another quality that adds to the accuracy of the gun.  Lastly, the polymer frame is absolutely solid, not a millimeter of bend or sway on any of the extremities of the gun. Especially in the dust cover area, where on the Glock it is notable that its dust cover does not seem to be molded straight. This is due to the dust cover of the Glock being too thin and that the frame is taken out if its mold before it is absolutely cool during the manufacturing process.  The Steyr simply does not have this problem.

I love Glock pistols, I am simply stating the superiority of this product and stand by it. 
Fun fact these series of Steyr pistols were designed by Gaston Glock himself.  It is not too hard to get one of these but also it is rare in Michigan.
